audio_caption: The audio clip begins with the upbeat sound of a samba-style percussion arrangement. This abruptly cuts out, transitioning into the distinct voice of a male speaker. He begins, in a calm, conversational tone, by noting how "our lives all revolve around the internet." He then asks the audience, seemingly at a live event, "How many of you go on Facebook...?" and prompts a show of hands. Continuing, he asks further questions, such as "How many of you here would not even remember your friend's birthdays if not for Facebook?" and "How many of you here watch YouTube more than you watch television now?" seemingly emphasizing the influence of the internet in peoples' daily lives. The audio concludes with the same energetic samba music from the beginning.

The audio clip consists of a single male speaker discussing how easily we can find information online nowadays, noting that everything we want to know is available and more information is being added daily, making it easier to access. The speech is delivered in a casual, conversational tone.

The audio clip features one male speaker with a casual tone discussing how accessing information online has become easier over the last decade, referencing Google and Wikipedia. He emphasizes the convenience of having information readily available from home.

The audio clip starts with one male speaker, who conveys a tone of optimism and enthusiasm. He mentions that "you don't have to go to a library anymore" and emphasizes the ease of finding information online. The tone remains positive as he asserts that "nobody's gonna stop you from finding what you're looking for".

A single male speaker reflects on the internet. He notes the "great freedom" it provides but expresses concern that it can make us "spoiled." He mentions we might not value information as much when it's readily accessible, questioning the point of seeking it out, suggesting "we lose the value of them." His tone is contemplative and thoughtful.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker excitedly talking about a realization he had last summer when he decided to create a game. He describes his background as a non-professional programmer and the motivation behind creating "When Pigs Fly".  He discusses the game as a summer project and learning experience. The overall tone is enthusiastic and reflective.

The clip starts with a male speaker discussing how people nowadays often use search engines like Google to learn things, giving the examples of creating an app or making a game, and changing search queries to find relevant results. He speaks in a casual and conversational tone. He then states that when people are researching things, that is pretty much all they have to do, and this is what he did.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing how he was searching for a framework on his first day and found one that seemed easy to learn, saying he thought it would be "fun" to "try it out". He speaks in an enthusiastic tone.

A male speaker begins by describing his unsuccessful research on a new framework, noting it was too new and unlike popular software with readily available tutorials. He mentions that his online searches only yielded basic information. The speaker's tone is somewhat frustrated.

The audio clip features a single male speaker who sounds thoughtful and conversational. He narrates a personal experience, explaining how he "ran into some trouble" and had to figure out "now what." He then describes trying to research the basics and learn, spending time "trying to get grasp to these basics" and "playing with them on my own." He emphasizes that it's something he hadn't done before.

A single male speaker recounts how he and his friends developed a game. He mentions receiving feedback that inspired them to "progress this" and "add some more." He then describes it metaphorically, stating he "got all these ingredients to make a burger," but did not know what to do with them. Eventually, "we got our burger done" and the game was named "When Pigs Fly". After that, he gathered his friends, and they worked on the graphics and game concepts, and eventually "came up with this."

The audio starts with a person introducing screenshots for a game. Describing it as rather simple, explaining the objective is to tap and maneuver a pig across the sky to eat food, while avoiding birds. Mentioning it was done in about a month, and the speaker expresses being happy and having had a great time creating the game, learning a lot and getting something done, accompanied by audible nervousness.

The audio clip starts with upbeat, somewhat generic pop music, which creates a cheerful mood. Then, a male speaker begins to discuss the value of online information. He speaks in a thoughtful and slightly earnest tone, emphasizing that information should be used for learning rather than passively consumed. The pop music fades out as the speaker continues his explanation.

The audio begins with a single male speaker, conversational in tone, discussing learning to play the guitar. He mentions how people often go online to find tabs and play songs, but he emphasizes the importance of using what you learn to create your own songs, adding that most people don't do this.

The audio clip contains a speech from a male speaker. He talks about cooking and how people nowadays follow recipes online without diving deeper into the learning process. He then relates this to students and how they start research by visiting Wikipedia. The speaker's tone is conversational and engaging. In the background, there is a consistent humming sound.

The clip begins with a male speaker talking about contributing to Wikipedia, noting that fewer hands went up when asked about contributing. He encourages the audience to share what they know online and to share the things that they've learned.  He speaks in an enthusiastic and positive tone. He ends his talk with "Thank you". Applause is then heard.  Lastly, a musical interlude begins featuring a percussion section playing fast-tempo, slightly chaotic-sounding music.
